discovers.name: Pedra da Cebola Park
discovers.address: R. Ana Viêira Mafra, s/n - Mata da Praia, Vitória - ES, 29066-010
discovers.description: Pedra da Cebola Park is located between 'Jardim da Penha' and 'Mata da Praia'. The park measures 100,005 square meters and has typical restinga vegetation.

discovers.name: Camburi Beach
discovers.description: It's the longest beach in Vitória, with total length of 6km.

discovers.name: Vale Botanical Park
discovers.address: Av. dos Expedicionários, s/n - Jardim Camburi, Vitória - ES, 29090-070
discovers.description: The Vale Botanical Park is located in the Tubarão Port Industrial Complex. The Park is located within Vale's Green Belt and reveals the process of forest restoration and preservation of the Atlantic Forest.

discovers.name: Boi Island
discovers.description: Boi Island is an island-neighborhood, the island got its name because it was the residence of oxen that arrived on the island of Vitória in the colonial period.

discovers.name: Anchieta Palace
discovers.address: Praça João Clímaco, s/n - Centro, Vitória - ES, 29015-110
discovers.description: Anchieta Palace is the seat of the executive power of the state of Espírito Santo, Brazil. The palace is located directly in front of Vitória Port.

discovers.name: The Convent of Nossa Senhora do Monte do Carmo
discovers.address: Praça Irmã Joséfa Hosana, 5 - Centro, Vitória - ES, 29015-560
discovers.description: The Convent of Nossa Senhora do Monte do Carmo is a Catholic temple founded in 1682 in the city of Vitória, capital of Espírito Santo.

discovers.name: Namorados Square
discovers.description: The square is well know for being one of the main regular stops for dates of many couples and hangout with friends.

discovers.name: Bermuda Triangle - Vitória
discovers.address: R. João da Cruz - Praia do Canto, Vitória - ES, 29055-460
discovers.description: The Bermuda Triangle comprises the stretch between 'Joaquim Lírio' and 'João da Cruz' streets. It received this name because people frequently got lost with friends in the local bars and restaurants, often returning to their homes only at dawn.
